discussion.content: I don't think the answer is correct. It should be B. The apache patch that was released was for version 2.4.1 and later I.e higher version. Therefore it does not apply to 192.168.1.22

comments.content: yep. or the question maker purposely didn't show the results for 192.168.1.21 to confuse us.

discussion.content: got it right but a horrible question because in reality the answer applies to two boxes not just one

questions.question_text: A security analyst notices PII has been copied from the customer database to an anonymous FTP server in the DMZ. Firewall logs indicate the customer database has not been accessed from anonymous FTP server. Which of the following departments should make a decision about pursuing further investigation? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
A. Just nope.
B. Another nope.
C. Nope, because the data has NOT YET been stolen.
D. Always yes.
E. Obvious yes.
I think it should be C and D. Legal since this can be a potential data breach of PII. Upper Management since they should be notified of any potential data breach/incidents.

Should be IT and Legal
IT to investigate the infra and Legal for the PII.
executives doesnt usually gets involves unless it causes a big impact on the companay and its reputation
Y did is one option been choosen when it ask to choose 2

I think the answers should be D and E. 
IT Dept has to be involved because of the breach and the executive management has to be involved to make a decision.
Exec mgmt, as somebody from another dept copied the file to an FTP server, and the IT dept is in charge of the FTP server -- that's two separate depts, so need to involve exec

comments.content: This makes sense. Retracting my old comments. I think there's no need to involve legal on this one since the potential data breach is only internal, customer database copied to anonymous ftp server in DMZ, and which HAS NOT BEEN ACCESSED per FW logs. So, yep, D and E.

discussion.content: I think it should be D and E. E as the IT Dept should have knowledge and recommendations. D as any investigation needs to be ok'd by the management.
I feel legal and IT should be involved
I think it's B. External users won't be using the local DNS server to access the the company's website.
I doesn't make any sense choosing B as the Answer. If the DNS was misconfigured? How would external users be able to connect to the website? I think the less stupid option is A.
I would agree as the only option answer is fqdn and its a public website. Meaning your not going to be using an fqdn to connect to it. only valid answer is b then.
Is this really B? If the dns server is corrupted, then they shoudn't be able to access any sites at all.

choices.C: The time synchronization server is corrupted.

questions.question_text: A security analyst received several service tickets reporting that a company storefront website is not accessible by internal domain users. However, external users are accessing the website without issue. Which of the following is the MOST likely reason for this behavior?
Which of the following utilities could be used to resolve an IP address to a domain name, assuming the address has a PTR record?

A security analyst has just completed a vulnerability scan of servers that support a business critical application that is managed by an outside vendor. The results of the scan indicate the devices are missing critical patches. Which of the following factors can inhibit remediation of these vulnerabilities? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Inhibitors of Remediation
MOU
SLA
IT Governance
Business Process Interruption
 ยง Degrading Functionality

A. Not related.
B. Yes, because we're talking about INHIBITION, which means it "stands in the way of". If not part of the SLA, the vendor may not be compelled to remediate the vulnerabilities.
C. Absolutely. When a critical business process is involved, management may not be so keen on downtime of a server, even if it is for patching.
D. Nope, because this should be part of your vulnerability management process. It can save you time in production by testing patches in staging.
E. It might slow you down, but not stop you.
specifies management by outside vendor... So i would chose B & C

comments.content: I disagree. Sla is not going to slow down any updates. These are business critical servers. So downtime and sandbox testing will be primary issues. C & D

Yes it might. In fact, if it's not clearly defined in your SLA, remediation might not even be required for a vendor: "SLAs exist to outline what the roles and responsibilities are for the service providers, including the limit of the services they can perform. Unless remediation is explicitly part of an SLA, providers cannot be compelled to perform those steps."
